|Title=Knowing the diagnostic criteria for a hypersecretory nodule
|Description=None
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Magalie Haissaguerre,Camille Buffet
|Order=11}}

Hyperthyroidism can be induced by a single hypersecreting nodule (toxic adenoma) or by a toxic multinodular goitre (several hypersecreting nodules).

It is the leading cause of hyperthyroidism in the elderly.

The diagnostic criteria for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre therefore include:

- Clinical: a thyrotoxicosis syndrome of variable intensity

- Hormonal profile: peripheral biological hyperthyroidism (low TSH) of variable intensity (= increased or normal T4 and/or T3).

- Ultrasound: a nodule or several nodules on thyroid ultrasound

- Scintigraphy: a single hyperfixing area with extinction of healthy thyroid parenchyma (if single adenoma = toxic adenoma) or alternating hot and cold fixation areas known as a checkerboard pattern (if multiple toxic nodules).

question.question: What are the diagnostic criteria for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre?
question.option_a: Clinical: thyrotoxicosis syndrome, Hormonal profile: low TSH, Ultrasound: normal thyroid ultrasound, Scintigraphy: healthy thyroid parenchyma
question.option_b: Clinical: thyrotoxicosis syndrome, Hormonal profile: peripheral biological hyperthyroidism, Ultrasound: a nodule or several nodules, Scintigraphy: a single hyperfixing area
question.option_c: Clinical: euthyroidism, Hormonal profile: normal TSH, Ultrasound: multiple nodules, Scintigraphy: alternating hot and cold fixation areas
question.option_d: Clinical: myxedema, Hormonal profile: high TSH, Ultrasound: a single nodule, Scintigraphy: healthy thyroid parenchyma
